Name: Writing Fantasy & Science Fiction: How to Create Out-of-This-World Novels and Short Stories

ReviewList.Text: I hope prospective buyers will notice that this is a reprint of two old books, Orson Scott Card's "How to Write Science Fiction & Fantasy", first published way back in 1990; and "The Writer's Complete Fantasy Reference", first published in 2000.  Sandwiched between them is an essay on steampunk and an essay on "The State of the Genre" (the latter written by a writer who has no real claim to be considered a serious writer or particularly successful within the genre in any case).
I didn't think I would finish reading this book but I can't put it down. Lots of great insights.

Although I enjoyed the subject matter of the book, it really consists of some history of the genres, a chapter on "Steampunk", and the rest is just a big glossary of terminology involved mainly in fantasy lit.  So if you're looking for help on actually writing in these genres you'll be disappointed.
This was given as a gift to a budding sci fi writer-- the reaction I got was phenomenal, and I really hope he finds writing wisdom from people in the field.

It was just two books I had already read streamlined together. Waste of time. No new material here. The Orson Scott Card book was good. But really this book as its presents is somewhat false advertising. blah.
